nodes.bodyText: wonder if we have a util for this somewhere
I can not find one.
am sure there is a util in guava or xtext this somewhere

The only existing method that does more or less the same is org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils#isBlank. But it is in a jar not currently in the classpath of the project. I would avoid adding a dependency just because of this tiny method.
@szarnekow do you have an idea?
eclipse/xtext-lib#247
CharMatcher.whitespace().matchesAllOf(..)

I see but am not convinced that it would be an improvement.
"line.trim.empty" vs. "CharMatcher.whitespace().matchesAllOf(line)" ... for me it is not more clear and longer AND depend on third party code ... I would not change it ...
com.google.common.base.Strings.commonPrefix(CharSequence, CharSequence) may be handy here, too along with isBlank

Have thought about this a bit. As the existing method computes the prefix for only two strings I would have to iterate all the lines, compute the common prefix with the first line, then take the shortest prefix, remove everything after the last whitespace, then return it. Do not believe it will be a noticeable improvement.
It was only an idea. We could use common prefix without that replace operation.
Ok, you are right. In case of inconsistent usage of blanks and tabs we will get wired results in any case. With or without the replace operation. In any case your solution is much more readable.

Because of the skipping of the first line ... maybe I get you wrong, but in your example we do not want to remove any leading whitespace ... because of the first line. In this sense it is the counter example ... we need to consider the first line.

I see. In that case the algorithm will not work. On the other hand the complete rule will be misformatted in case we skip the first line. Guess it is not possible to make every case 100% "correct" ... hence we have to try to make the most common cases good looking. And the complete rule is probably the most important case.
Nice nice!
I thought we'd need that for the line ending?
ok
This should use the line ending from the code config
Ok.

commonLeadingWhitespace ignores blank lines. Let's assume we do have three lines:

   text
 
   more text

The commonWhitespace should be 3.
The second line has only a single char, though. I'd assume that the logic in line 420 will now fail: lines.get(1).substring(3) will throw an IOOBE.
I'd say blank lines should be replaced by the prefix itself.
Good catch. Will fix.
If we'd use \\s*(\\r?\\n) we'd automatically righttrim the lines and avoid dangling whitespace in the generated grammar access. What do you think?
Yes, good idea.
Not sure if we should treat indentation by tabs specially here.
Now we do. Replace each tab with four space to handle the common case where we indent with tabs.
Added this case for single lines.
